“Design a personalized health-portal to help cancer patients make better informed decisions about diagnosis and treatment”

Overview

We are Jam + Yarrow, a a team of five Carnegie Mellon University graduate students who worked together on a capstone project for Ventana Medical Systems.

We conducted research and conceptualized a digital product that would help cancer patients make better informed decisions regarding diagnosis and treatment.

Our Process

Research

Analysis

Design

Research

We began our research by reviewing online resources and following cancer support forums. We explored various decision-support tools available to cancer patients, which helped us identify gaps in the current market landscape.
We then began engaging with cancer patients directly by visiting local support groups and speaking to cancer experts at the Hillman Cancer Center, UPMC.

Our focus was on patients diagnosed with common cancers (e.g. breast, prostate or lung cancer) and who were in the diagnosis, treatment selection or treatment administration phases of their cancer journey.
We wanted to better understand the patient’s cancer journey, key needs, desires and challenges. Also, to explore how cancer patients interact with their medical data, especially in relation to organizing, tracking, and sharing information.

analysis

We began our analysis by reviewing online resources and following cancer support forums. We explored various decision-support tools available to cancer patients, which helped us identify gaps in the current market landscape.
We then began engaging with cancer patients directly by visiting local support groups and speaking to cancer experts at the Hillman Cancer Center, UPMC.

Our focus was on patients diagnosed with common cancers (e.g. breast, prostate or lung cancer) and who were in the diagnosis, treatment selection or treatment administration phases of their cancer journey.
We wanted to better understand the patient’s cancer journey, key needs, desires and challenges. Also, to explore how cancer patients interact with their medical data, especially in relation to organizing, tracking, and sharing information.

I'm unique

Cancer patients are hungry for more individualized data and care

Hyper-individualized information can help patients create a road-map that better prepares them for what’s ahead, and aids them in making better-informed decisions throughout the cancer journey. The result is a drastic improvement in treatment outcomes and cancer patient quality of life.

I'm making trade-offs

Cancer patients’ personal preferences drive their medical decisions

Many cancer patients don’t allow their lives to revolve around their illness. Therefore, personal preferences play a big role in cancer related decision making, throughout diagnosis, treatment selection, and the treatment phases.Patients find themselves constantly making treatment trade-offs without proper decision support.

I'm overwhelmed

Cancer patients struggle with making data meaningful

Although information can be empowering, too much of it makes it hard for somebody undergoing cancer treatment to filter out trustworthy and relevant information. Even when patients or caregivers are able to identify credible, relevant and specific information, they often have trouble making sense of it. Much of this kind of information is not written with the cancer patient as the end-user in mind.

I'm not fighting alone

Cancer patients often rely on others to manage the minutia of treatment and care

In many cases, a cancer patient’s primary caretaker is a family member who plays a critical role in helping their loved one. But cancer related information is new to caregivers as well and they need access to answers and tools that allow them to stay involved. Additionally, since multiple doctors are involved in the cancer patient’s care, having to coordinate between them and share-out information can drain both patients and caregivers.

Cancer patients make life-critical decisions. They are constantly searching for information that could help them evaluate their condition and make better-informed decisions. We identified two different approaches to seeking information:

Social-driven actions

Receiving support

The experience of peers in a similar situation helps cancer patients to know what to expect.

Giving support

Cancer survivors can become advocates and give back by sharing their stories with others.

Data-driven actions

Research

Cancer patients feel like they are in control of the situation by having a better understanding of their medical data.

Tracking

During and after treatment, cancer patients track data related to their medications, side effects, food habits, etc.

Our goal is to contribute significantly towards improving the cancer care experience of a patient, by designing a human-centered solution that supports the data and social needs of people diagnosed with cancer.

design

We began our design by reviewing online resources and following cancer support forums. We explored various decision-support tools available to cancer patients, which helped us identify gaps in the current market landscape.
We then began engaging with cancer patients directly by visiting local support groups and speaking to cancer experts at the Hillman Cancer Center, UPMC.

Our focus was on patients diagnosed with common cancers (e.g. breast, prostate or lung cancer) and who were in the diagnosis, treatment selection or treatment administration phases of their cancer journey.
We wanted to better understand the patient’s cancer journey, key needs, desires and challenges. Also, to explore how cancer patients interact with their medical data, especially in relation to organizing, tracking, and sharing information.
